newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada allows toxic PCB waste exports to U.S.
newsitem.headline: Canada allows toxic PCB waste exports to U.S.

text.p: Canadian Environment Minister Sergio Marchi on Thursday said Canada has decided to allow highly toxic PCB waste to be shipped to the United States for destruction.

"The regulations ensure that Canadian PCB wastes exported to the United States cannot be landfilled, but must be sent to U.S. Environmental Protection Agency approved facilities for thermal, chemical or other forms of destruction," Environment Canada said in a press release.
PCBs, or polychlorinated biphenyls, were imported in Canada from the United States in the 1930s and used mainly in the production of electrical equipment.

In 1990 Canada adopted legislation banning the exports of PCBs to all countries except the United States. The exception was made to allow U.S.-government owned PCBs in Canada to be returned to the United States for disposal, Environment Canada said.
Canada is legally boud by the Basel Convention, which it ratified in 1992, to ensure that all exported PCBs are managed in an environmentally safe way.
